title: How to Connect Two Different AirPods to One Case + Fixes

steps.title: Open the Settings app on your device.
steps.content: Open the Settings app on your device. If you’ve had to replace one of your AirPods, Apple recommends unpairing your AirPods from your iPhone, iPad, or iPod touch and then re-pairing them . [1] X Research source First, go to the Home Screen on your device and launch the Settings app. This will work on AirPods 1, AirPods 2, AirPods 3, AirPods Pro, and AirPods 4. Just be sure the AirPods you're trying to pair are from the same generation.

steps.title: Select Bluetooth.
steps.content: Select Bluetooth . It’s near the top of the Settings menu.

steps.title: Tap the Information button next to your AirPods.
steps.content: Tap the Information button next to your AirPods. You should see your AirPods listed under My Devices . Tap the Info button (it looks like a blue circle with a lowercase i inside) next to your AirPods. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Select Forget Device and confirm your choice.
steps.content: Select Forget Device and confirm your choice. On the next screen, tap Forget This Device . A confirmation menu will pop up at the bottom of the screen. Select Forget Device . You may be prompted to tap it a second time to confirm your choice. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Put both AirPods in the charging case with the lid open.
steps.content: Put both AirPods in the charging case with the lid open. Put your new AirPod in the charging case along with the old one. Don’t close the lid. [4] X Research source At this point, you should notice that the status light on the case is flashing amber. This means that the case recognizes a pairing or connectivity issue between your AirPods.

steps.title: Press and hold the setup button until the light flashes white.
steps.content: Press and hold the setup button until the light flashes white. Locate the setup button on the back of the case and hold it down for a few seconds. This will reset the case and the AirPods . Once the process is complete, the light will begin to flash white. [5] X Research source If the status light doesn't flash white, do the following: AirPods 1, 2, 3, or AirPods Pro : With the lid open, press and hold the setup button on the back of the case for 15 seconds until the light flashes amber, and then white. AirPods 4 : With the status light on, double-tap the front of the case, double-tap again when it flashes white, and double-tap a third time when the status light flashes quicker. It should flash amber, and then white.

steps.title: Hold the open AirPods case close to your device.
steps.content: Hold the open AirPods case close to your device. Return to the Home Screen on your iPhone, iPad, or iPod touch and hold the AirPods case close to it. Keep the lid open and make sure both AirPods are in the case.

steps.title: Tap Connect on the setup animation.
steps.content: Tap Connect on the setup animation. Once the AirPods are in range, a setup animation will pop up on your device’s screen. Select Connect , then tap Done to finish the connection process.

steps.title: Make sure your AirPods are both the same generation.
steps.content: Make sure your AirPods are both the same generation. If your AirPods are different generations or different models, you won’t be able to get them to work together. Before buying a replacement AirPod, check to make sure it’s the same kind as your other AirPod. You’ll also need to make sure the new AirPod is compatible with your charging case. Depending on which version of iOS you’re using, there are a couple ways to do this: In iOS 14 and later, open Settings on your iPhone, iPad, or iPod touch, then select Bluetooth . Tap the Information button next to your AirPods (it looks like a blue circle with an i in it). You’ll see the model name and number listed in the About section. [6] X Research source In earlier versions of iOS, open Settings , General , and then About . Locate your AirPods in your list of connected devices and tap their name for more information, including the model name and number. You can also find the model number listed on the AirPods themselves. Check out Apple’s list of AirPod and charging case models for compatibility information.

steps.title: Charge your case if you can’t get it to reset.
steps.content: Charge your case if you can’t get it to reset. If you’ve tried holding down the reset button on the case but can’t get it to change from amber to white, the case might need to be charged . With both AirPods still inside, close the charger lid and connect it to a power supply for 20 minutes. [7] X Research source Open the lid and hold down the setup button again until it flashes white. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Check that both AirPods are charged.
steps.content: Check that both AirPods are charged. If you still can’t get your AirPods to work together, make sure both of them are charged. Check that the case is fully charged, then place the AirPods in it and let them charge for at least 30 seconds. Open the case near your iPhone, iPad, or iPod touch and look at the status display to make sure both AirPods are charging. [9] X Research source If one of them still isn’t charging or doesn’t show up on the display, try resetting the AirPods again.

steps.title: Clean your AirPods if you’re having trouble hearing one of them.
steps.content: Clean your AirPods if you’re having trouble hearing one of them. If your AirPods both seem to be charged and connected properly, but you still can’t hear out of one of them, it’s possible that dirt or lint is blocking up the speaker port. [10] X Research source Carefully clean your AirPods by wiping them down with a soft cloth. Brush the speaker ports with an anti-static brush to remove set-in grime. [11] X Research source You may also need to fix the audio balance in your device’s Accessibility settings.
